required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Investigating Accelerated Learning and Memory in Healthy Subjects Using a Face Name Memory Task
clinical_study.official_title: Investigating Accelerated Learning and Memory in Healthy Subjects Using a Face Name Memory Task

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas at Dallas

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas at Dallas

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to investigate whether we can accelerate learning and improve associative memory performance in healthy subjects by applying transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS) during a Face Name memory task.

detailed_description.textblock:
Associative memory refers to remembering the association between two items, such as a face and a name or a word in English and the same word in another language. It is not only important for learning, but it is also one of the first aspects of memory performance that is impacted by aging and by Alzheimer׳s disease. For decades, neuroscientists have investigated associative learning and memory and ways to accelerate and enhance associative learning and memory.
Transcranial Direct Current stimulation (tDCS) is a non-invasive and painless electrical stimulation technique that has demonstrated to accelerate learning and improve memory in some studies. To investigate whether we can accelerate learning and improve associative memory using tDCS, we will compare the performance in a Face Name Associate memory task from 2 groups. The first group will get active tDCS during the study phase of the Face Name Memory task, whereas the second group will get sham tDCS during the study phase of the task.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: (1) active tDCS with Face Name associate memory task (2) sham tDCS with Face Name associate memory task

primary_outcome.measure: Associative Memory Assessed by a Face Name Associate Memory Experiment
primary_outcome.time_frame: Associate Memory is assessed after a 10 minutes break following the study phase
primary_outcome.description: All participants performed a face memory task .The face stimuli consisted of 120 grayscale pictures of human faces. Only faces with a neutral expression facing forward were selected. Half of the faces were male, and the other half were female. The face-name association memory task was divided into (1) an encoding phase, (2) a consolidation phase, and (3) a retrieval phase. During the encoding phase, participants studied 60 successively presented face-name pairs and were instructed to assess their gender to keep them focused to the task. The encoding phase was followed by a consolidation phase where participants were instructed to "sit still, relax, and think about nothing in particular" for 10 minutes, During the retrieval phase, participants were presented with 60 old and 60 new faces and were instructed to assess whether they have seen this face during the encoding phase. The outcome was the percent of Correct Name to Face Matches

arm_group.description: active tDCS with Face Name associate Memory task
sham tDCS with Face Name associate Memory task

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age: 18-35 years
- Native English Speaker
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of severe head injuries, epileptic insults, or heart disease.
- Severe psychiatric disorders and severe untreated medical problems.
- Contraindications for tDCS (pregnant women, implanted devices)

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Beck Depression Inventory Scale
measure.description: The Beck Depression Inventory (BDI, BDI-1A, BDI-II), created by Aaron T. Beck, is a 21-question multiple-choice self-report inventory, one of the most widely used psychometric tests for measuring the severity of depression. The Beck Depression Inventory uses the following scale to assess patients: 0 - 13: Minimal depression, 14 - 19: Mild depression, 20 - 28: Moderate depression, 29 - 63: Severe depression Min score: 0; Max Score: 63; The higher the score the more mood

measure.title: Beck Anxiety Inventory Scale
measure.description: The Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI), created by Aaron T. Beck and other colleagues, is a 21-question multiple-choice self-report inventory that is used for measuring the severity of anxiety in children and adults. The BAI contains 21 questions, each answer being scored on a scale value of 0 (not at all) to 3 (severely). Higher total scores indicate more severe anxiety symptoms. The standardized cutoffs[4] are: 0-7: minimal anxiety 8-15: mild anxiety 16-25: moderate anxiety 26-63: severe anxiety

measure.title: Mini Mental State Examination
measure.description: The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) or Folstein test is a 30-point questionnaire that is used extensively in clinical and research settings to measure cognitive impairment. Any score of 24 or more (out of 30) indicates a normal cognition. Below this, scores can indicate severe (≤9 points), moderate (10-18 points) or mild (19-23 points) cognitive impairment.

measure.title: Profile of Mood States- Mood Disturbance
measure.description: The Profile of Mood States (POMS) is a psychological rating scale used to access transient, distinct mood states. The total score is reported. The higher the score the more people are sensitive to mood swings. Min score 0 - Max score is 148.

outcome.title: Associative Memory Assessed by a Face Name Associate Memory Experiment
outcome.description: All participants performed a face memory task .The face stimuli consisted of 120 grayscale pictures of human faces. Only faces with a neutral expression facing forward were selected. Half of the faces were male, and the other half were female. The face-name association memory task was divided into (1) an encoding phase, (2) a consolidation phase, and (3) a retrieval phase. During the encoding phase, participants studied 60 successively presented face-name pairs and were instructed to assess their gender to keep them focused to the task. The encoding phase was followed by a consolidation phase where participants were instructed to "sit still, relax, and think about nothing in particular" for 10 minutes, During the retrieval phase, participants were presented with 60 old and 60 new faces and were instructed to assess whether they have seen this face during the encoding phase. The outcome was the percent of Correct Name to Face Matches
outcome.time_frame: Associate Memory is assessed after a 10 minutes break following the study phase

measure.title: Associative Memory Assessed by a Face Name Associate Memory Experiment
measure.description: All participants performed a face memory task .The face stimuli consisted of 120 grayscale pictures of human faces. Only faces with a neutral expression facing forward were selected. Half of the faces were male, and the other half were female. The face-name association memory task was divided into (1) an encoding phase, (2) a consolidation phase, and (3) a retrieval phase. During the encoding phase, participants studied 60 successively presented face-name pairs and were instructed to assess their gender to keep them focused to the task. The encoding phase was followed by a consolidation phase where participants were instructed to "sit still, relax, and think about nothing in particular" for 10 minutes, During the retrieval phase, participants were presented with 60 old and 60 new faces and were instructed to assess whether they have seen this face during the encoding phase. The outcome was the percent of Correct Name to Face Matches
measure.units: Percent of Correct Name to Face Matches

analysis.non_inferiority_desc: To compare the old and new faces' hit rate, we calculated the true positive rate (TPR: the proportion of positives that are correctly identified as such). A repeated measures ANOVA was conducted with the TPR for both old and new faces as within-subjects variable and group (active vs sham) as between-subjects variable.
analysis.estimate_desc: Difference between active tDCS and sham tDCS

reported_events.desc: At the end of the stimulation procedure, participants complete an exit questionnaire on which they can report side-effects from the study.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
